In the philosophy of Gilles Deleuze and Félix Guattari, minor literature is a form of deterritorialization that is relative to the dominant culture and its language. Deterritorialization is the process by which established systems, structures, and meanings are disrupted and transformed, and minor literature is a form of deterritorialization that challenges the dominant culture and its language.

Minor literature is relative to the dominant culture in the sense that it challenges and resists the dominant culture and its language, rather than attempting to assimilate to it or align with it. It is a form of resistance to the dominant culture and its power structures, and it creates new meanings and connections that are alternative to those of the dominant culture.

However, minor literature is also an absolute form of deterritorialization in the sense that it creates new connections and meanings that are not simply a reaction to the dominant culture, but rather a distinct and alternative way of being in the world. Minor literature represents a break with the dominant culture and its language, and it allows for the creation of new identities and ways of being that are not beholden to the dominant culture.

Overall, minor literature is a form of relative deterritorialization that challenges and resists the dominant culture, while also creating new and distinct connections and meanings that are alternative to those of the dominant culture.
